contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "prostitution" represents the people being unfaithful to God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: great prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "house" means "family," including Jehu's descendants. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Jehu

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to kingdom of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the house of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mother" refers to the nation of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is stating that Israel, spoken of here as a woman, is no longer acting like a wife to Yahweh. Instead Israel has turned away from following and worshiping him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for she is not my wife

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh can no longer be in relationship with the nation of Israel as a husband would be to his wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: neither am I her husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: A wife who is adulterous leaves her husband to sleep with another man. This is how Israel was acting toward Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: her acts of adultery

contextId.occurrenceNote: This imagery suggests that Israel is relying on the idols and not Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: from between her breasts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will no longer protect and provide for Israel because the nation has turned away from him. In Israel, husbands were obliged by law to provide clothes for their wives. Not to do so was a sign that a man was rejecting his wife. The full meaning of this may be made clear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: I will strip her naked and show her nakedness as on the day that she was born

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "thirst" refers to the need to worship and rely on Yahweh, not idols, or Israel will not be able to survive as a nation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will make her die from thirst

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Israelites are acting like they do not belong to Yahweh. Just as their parents did not worship God, Neither do they. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for they are children of prostitution

contextId.occurrenceNote: The previous generation who sought out other gods were considered prostitutes for they were unfaithful to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For their mother has been a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage indicates that Yahweh will prevent his people from finding success and prosperity, becuase they continue to worship idols. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Therefore I will build up a hedge to block her way with thorns. I will build up a wall against her so she cannot find her way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel will return to Yahweh not because of their love for him, but because they are disappointed by their worship of Baal. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Then she will say, "I will return to my first husband, for it was better for me then than it is now."

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will humiliate the people of Israel in front of the other nations nearby. See how you translated this in [Hosea 2:3](../02/03.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Then I will strip her naked in the sight of her lovers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to payment that Israel received from the false gods or Baals. This direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. Alternate translation: "that these were the wages that her lovers had given to her" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-quotations]])
contextId.glQuote: These are the wages that my lovers gave me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will destroy the vineyards and fruit trees by allowing other trees and weeds to grow among them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make them a forest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh hopes that the nation of Israel will repent and again choose to worship him as their God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: She will answer me there as she did in the days of her youth, as in the days that she came out of the land of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the people of Israel will love and be faithful to Yahweh just as a wife is to a husband. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My husband

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Baal" means "master" and also refers to the false god that the Canaanites worship. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My Baal

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will be like the husband, and Israel will be like Yahweh's wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will promise to be your husband forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the name of this valley stands for all the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Jezreel

contextId.occurrenceNote: When God makes his people safe and prosperous in their land again, they are spoken of if they were agricultural crops. Alternate translation: "I will take care of the Israelite people as a farmer plants his crops and takes care of them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will plant her for myself in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stating that the people of Israel have sinned against him and broken his covenant is spoken of as if Yahweh were accusing them in court. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has a lawsuit against the inhabitants of the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bounds" stands for the limits of what the law allows. Alternate translation: "The people have disobeyed the law in every possible way" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The people have broken all bounds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "stumble" means to disobey God or even to stop trusting him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You priests will stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "mother" refers to the nation of Israel. See how you translated this in [Hosea 2:2](../02/02.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will destroy your mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: has convinced the people to sin (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has misled

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will destroy the nation of Israel because they do not understand or obey God's commandments. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: So this people who does not understand will be thrown down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to emphasize that he cannot continue to take care of the people because they are stubborn. Yahweh no longer taking care of his people is spoken of as if he were a shepherd that could not take his lambs into the field to eat because they are stubborn. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will not shepherd a rebellious people." or "Therefore Yahweh will not continue to take care of them." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How can Yahweh bring them to pasture like lambs in a meadow?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "wind" represents God's judgment and anger against the nation of Israel. Yahweh will allow the enemy army to defeat the people of Israel and take them as captives. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: The wind will wrap her up in its wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "rebels" refers to all of those people who had turned away from Yahweh, and "deep in slaughter" could refer to the murder of innocent people, or to the slaughter of animals offered to pagan idols. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The rebels stand deep in slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's wrath against Judah will be like a large stream of water that destroys them. In the scriptures, emotions and moral qualities are often spoken of as if they were liquids. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will pour my wrath on them like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "walked" represents the idea of worshiping. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walked after idols

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both Ephraim (the northern kingdom of Israel) and Judah (the southern kingdom of Israel) realized that they were in danger. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah saw his wound

contextId.occurrenceNote: As a lion tears apart the animal it is eating, so Yahweh will tear his people away from their homes and country. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will tear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Try to come into God's presence by means of worship and sacrifice. Alternate translation: "ask me to pay attention to them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: seek my face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Through his prophets, Yahweh has pronounced destruction on the rebellious nation. The destruction, here called "cutting to pieces," is as sure as the condemnation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: So I have cut them to pieces by the prophets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "harvest" represents God's final judgment on Israel and Judah. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making Israel obedient to God again and receivers of his blessing is spoken of as if it were healing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I want to heal Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people's evil deeds are probably spoken of here as if they were other people ready to accuse them of their crimes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their deeds surround them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people committed spiritual adultery by worshiping idols and being unfaithful to Yahweh. They were probably also being unfaithful to their husbands or wives by sleeping with other people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They are all adulterers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "smolders" means something is burning slowly without a flame. Alternate translation: "Their anger grows slowly and quietly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Their anger smolders

contextId.occurrenceNote: This seems to mean that the court officials kill their kings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they devour those who rule over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: However, this "old age" is clearly a way of saying that the northern kingdom is getting weaker and weaker, because the nation does not know it is "old." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but he does not know it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel's lack of interest in Yahweh is spoken of as if he was lost and they were not trying to find him. Alternate translation: "nor have they tried to get him to pay attention to them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: nor have they sought him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a way to catch birds. Yahweh continues to compare the people of Israel to doves. When they go to Egypt or Assyria for help, Yahweh will punish them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will spread my net over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here no longer worshiping God is spoken of as turning away from him. Alternate translation: "they no longer worship me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they turn away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This may be a military metaphor, in which God training the Israelites to love him and obey him is spoken of as if he had been training their men for war. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Though I trained them and strengthened their arms

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eagle, a bird of prey, is sometimes used to represent the enemies of Israel. Alternate translation: "As an eagle hunts another animal, the enemies of Israel are coming to capture my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: An eagle is coming over the house of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "broken" represents "disobeyed," "violated." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: broken my covenant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Anger is often spoken of as if it were a fire. Alternate translation: "I am very angry with these people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My anger is burning against these people

contextId.occurrenceNote: To sow or plant the wind is to act in useless or destructive ways. To reap the whirlwind is to suffer disaster from one's own actions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For the people sow the wind and reap the whirlwind

contextId.occurrenceNote: If any of Israel's actions do happen to result in something good, Israel's enemies will come and take it from them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If it does come to maturity, foreigners will devour it

contextId.occurrenceNote: "swallowed" means to be defeated and taken into exile. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "The enemies of Israel have taken the Israelites away to other lands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel is swallowed up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim's alliances with other nations are spoken of as if they had paid them to become prostitutes for Ephraim. Alternate translation: "The people of Israel have tried to pay other nations to protect them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim has hired lovers for herself

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is food that the Israelites would normally refuse to eat because it would make them unacceptable to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: unclean food

contextId.occurrenceNote: Briers growing in the places where Israelites stored their silver is spoken of as if the briers were human enemies that would take the Israelite's precious possessions for themselves. Alternate translation: "Sharp briers will grow where they store their treasures of silver" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: As for their treasures of silver—sharp briers will possess them

contextId.occurrenceNote: A "watchman" watches outside his city to see if danger is coming. The prophet warning the people when they are sinning and are in danger of having his God punish them is spoken of as if he were a watchman for the city. Alternate translation: "The prophet is like a watchman for God over Ephraim" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The prophet is the watchman for my God over Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: A "bird snare" is a trap used to catch a bird. This means the people of Israel do whatever they can to stop God's prophet. Alternate translation: "the people set a trap for him wherever he goes" or "the people do all they can to harm him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a bird snare is on all of his paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: When God stops helping the northern kingdom, it will be as if he physically turned away from them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when I turn away from them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the people being in a safe place as if they were a tree planted in a peaceful meadow. Alternate translation: "The nation of Israel was once beautiful and pleasant like the city of Tyre, like a tree that someone plants in a meadow" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have seen Ephraim, just like Tyre, planted in a meadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the people of Israel as if they were a diseased tree that does not produce fruit and is ready to be cut down. This is a statement that the people have become weak, and that soon their enemies will come and defeat them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim is diseased, and their root is dried up; they bear no fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel is spoken of as a vine that was very fruitful. For a while the people prospered and were strong. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel is a luxuriant vine that produces his fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: What they people called justice in their laws and legal decisions is spoken of as if it were a plant sprouting up. Alternate translation: "So their decisions are not just; instead, they are harmful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: So justice springs up like poisonous weeds in the furrows of a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This passage probably means that the people of the present time continue to act in the same ways that their ancestors did at Gibeah. Alternate translation: "and you think just as they did" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: there you have remained

contextId.occurrenceNote: A heifer loves to thresh because they can walk around freely without a yoke. Yahweh means that he has allowed the people of Israel to be free and have a pleasant life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim is a trained heifer that loves to thresh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "yoke" refers to suffering and slavery. Yahweh has been kind to the people of Israel, but the people have been unfaithful to him. So he will punish them and send them away as slaves. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will put a yoke on her fair neck. I will put a yoke on Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Judah" refers to the people of the southern kingdom and "Jacob" is the people of the northern kingdom. This means God will cause difficult times for both kingdoms. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah will plow; Jacob will pull the harrow by himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: Righteousness and covenant faithfulness are spoken of as if they were crops that could be sown and harvested. The abstract nouns "righteousness" and "faithfulness" can be stated as "right" and "faithful." Alternate translation: "Plow, now, and do what is right, and you will reap the fruit of faithful love" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Sow righteousness for yourselves, and reap the fruit of covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: When the ground is "unplowed" it is not ready to be planted. Yahweh means he wants the people to repent so they can start doing what is right. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Break up your unplowed ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wickedness and injustice are spoken of as if they were crops that could be sown and harvested. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have plowed wickedness; you reaped injustice

contextId.occurrenceNote: The result of deception are spoken of as if they were a food that could be eaten. Alternate translation: "You now suffer the consequences of having deceived each other" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have eaten the fruit of deception

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is speaking about the people of Israel as if they were a young man. Yahweh is referring to when he first started his relationship with the nation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When Israel was a young man

contextId.occurrenceNote: "son" refers to the people of God the Father. Alternate translation: "I led my son out of Egypt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I called my son out of Egypt

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh refers to Israel as a small child whom he taught to walk. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it was I who taught Ephraim to walk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping and honoring Yahweh is spoken of as if it were following him (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They will follow Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stating that the people of Judah have sinned against him and broken his covenant is spoken of as if Yahweh were accusing them in court. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Hosea 4:1](../04/01.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh also has a lawsuit against Judah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming wealthy by trading is spoken of as finding wealth. Alternate translation: "I have made much money" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have found wealth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The idea of making someone suffer the results of his own actions is spoken of as if those actions were objects that were thrown back at him. Alternate translation: "will make him suffer from his own disgraceful actions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will turn back on him his disgrace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "exalting" means to make oneself important. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He exalted himself in Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: When the people of Ephraim began worshiping Baal, they grew weak, and their enemies defeated them. Here "died" refers to the nation growing weak. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but he became guilty because of Baal worship, and he died

contextId.occurrenceNote: Becoming arrogant is spoken of as one's heart being lifted up. Alternate translation: "you became proud" (See:[[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your heart became lifted up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The northern kingdom's iniquity and guilt are spoken of as if they were objects that could be kept for a purpose. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has been stored up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh speaks of the suffering the people of Israel will suffer as if it were the pains of child birth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Pains of childbirth will come on him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh now describes the people of Israel as the baby to which the mother is giving birth. The baby is unwise because it does not want to be born. The people do not want to repent and obey Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but he is an unwise son, for when it is time to be born, he does not come out of the womb

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not to think about having compassion is spoken of as if compassion were hidden so that it cannot be seen. The abstract noun "compassion" can be translated with an adjective. Alternate translation: "I have no compassion for them" or "I will not be compassionate towards them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Compassion is hidden from my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression seems to stand for the nations around the northern kingdom, especially Judah, the southern kingdom. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his brothers

contextId.occurrenceNote: A wind from the east was very hot and destructive. Here it refers to the armies from the east that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: an east wind will come; the wind of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hosea continues to describe how God will punish the people of Israel. Here water represents life, vitality, and strength. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim's spring will dry up, and his well will have no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to all of the peoples' possessions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his storehouse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sinning is spoken of here as if it were falling. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for you have fallen because of your iniquity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Stopping the people from turning away from God is spoken of as if he were healing them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will heal their turning away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The failure of the people to obey God is spoken of as if they had physically turned away from him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their turning away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel will once again live protected by God. Israel is spoken of as living in his shade. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The people who live in his shade will return

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fruit" represents every good thing that comes from Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: from me comes your fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's commandments are spoken of as ways to walk in. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For the ways of Yahweh are right, and the righteous will walk in them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying Yahweh is spoken of as if it were stumbling while walking. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: stumble
